user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdEqual(osal_id_t object_id1, osal_id_t object_id2)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id1) == OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id2));
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any functions from <string.h> are present in the provided code fragments. The function OS_ForEachFilterCreator performs boolean checks and comparisons of object identifier values only; it does not copy, move, or inspect character buffers. The helper OS_ObjectIdEqual shown is an integer comparison via OS_ObjectIdToInteger and likewise contains no string handling. There is no use of memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, or any other string/byte-buffer operations in the supplied code, nor any pointer arithmetic or char-buffer access that could lead to out-of-bounds accesses. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided snippets that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
